normalized_summary: ailoop is a human-in-the-loop CLI tool that serves as a bridge between AI agents and human users, providing channel-based messaging for collecting human feedback through various interaction types including questions, authorizations, notifications, image display, and navigation suggestions.
goals: Serve as critical bridge between AI agents and human users
Prioritize human usability, accessibility, and safety
Provide reliable, secure, and respectful human input collection
Support channel-based messaging with complete isolation
Maintain high-quality Rust codebase with comprehensive testing
Ensure CLI-first architecture with server capabilities
Provide secure and private communication channels
Support semantic versioning with backward compatibility
actors: AI agents that invoke CLI commands
Human users who provide feedback and make decisions
Developers who build and maintain the tool
System administrators who deploy and manage servers
objects: CLI commands (ask, authorize, say, image, navigate)
Images and navigation URLs for user interaction
constraints: Human-centric design is non-negotiable
Test-first development with comprehensive test coverage (>80%)
Rust code must follow official style guide and formatting standards
CLI-first architecture with all capabilities accessible via command-line
Channel-based messaging with complete isolation between workflows
Exceptional security and privacy protection for human interactions
Strict semantic versioning for compatibility
All changes require corresponding documentation updates
Binary size must remain under 5MB for release builds
Maximum 100-character line lengths and consistent formatting
Server architecture must be standalone binary
No authentication and authorization for channels
No message persistence and history storage requirements
Initial platform support limited to Windows and Linux, macOS support later
Default timeout is zero, configured via config file in user profile or ad-hoc path
No multi-user scenarios supported
Logging limited to config folder (.ailoop directory)
No security protocols for channel communication
Standard channel naming convention: lowercase alphanumeric with hyphens/underscores, 1-64 chars, default 'public' channel
No specific performance requirements (tiny app that should perform well)
assumptions: Users have access to terminal/command-line interfaces
Network connectivity is available when server mode is used
Users understand basic CLI concepts and commands
Security concerns are addressed through proper Rust implementation
WebSocket communication is supported in deployment environments
Terminal interfaces support basic text formatting and colors
Users can provide timely responses to interactive prompts
